Fort Davis Texas
Monday July 19th 1880
Dear Mama
Papa has just written there is no use of my writing, but I'll do it anyhow. The officers gave an "hop" for Papa Saturday. He went & said he had a good time but  as I didn't know but a few & don't know how to dance. I staid at home. I would rather have been shot with a box of red hot tacks than go anywhere that evening. I didn't sleep very well though, I dreamed all night. I thought I saw a horse & buggy run away with you. The horse was killed buggy smashed and you half killed. I woke up after dreaming this scared and exhausted. I had a first class  stomach ache in the morning too. I'm all right now though.  I read another German book through in the last few days. I have not felt my sociable. Mrs. Ford Yard is the only lady I've called on. I felt more like reading than anything else and so passed my time that way. Gen. McLaughlin & I climbed up on the big rocky hill

unclear of the parade yesterday afternoon. The view is splendid. News has been rec'd that the Indians are moving toward Eagle Springs. the three companies from Concho and Capt. Levros Co. start today and we will probably get off  this afternoon. Lt. Beck is "A.A.A.G." and I'm Private Secretary to A.A.A.G and journalist besides being cork puller and handy jack generally. I  hope I can be of some use. There will be horses along for Papa, Lt. Beck the operator and me. Papa says he will make a courier and scout of me - this  would suit me. I drew the commissaries this morning and have been doing errands  for Papa. I hope we'll catch the Indians. I think Victoria is a remarkable military man. If a Co. of soldiers had escaped as often as he has and come out best so often with such odds against them it would be counted extraordinary. The paymaster has paid the troops already at least those who go into the field. I suppose Papa told you that Shannon had a couple of wagons considerable forage and several sets of harness burned up by a prairie fire. A soldier careless with fire was the cause. Major Woodward is Q.M. Commissary and

everything - he is very busy. I hope the campaign will be lively and successful. All well.

Affectionately

Robt. K. Grierson
P.S. We have had some washing done. - I saw Maria today. I think it is strange that I don't get any letters. There has certainly been time enough for me to receive letters if any of my numerous friends (?) have answered promptly.

Fort Concho Texas.
Friday, Oct. 22..1880.
My dear Bessie. 

                           It hardly seems possible that over four months have passed since I left Jacksonville. I meant to write long ago but many things prevented. I arrived 

June 2d. taking the folks by surprise. July 10., I left with my father for the wilderness "on the warpath". During my short stay here I wrote a good many letters, but when it was decided I should go on the scout, I concluded to wait, thinking it would be 'novel' to write you from "the field" or from El Paso. I took these photographs along to send to you; when this letter reaches you they will have traveled 3,400 miles - rather a round about way from Clendenon & Nichols to your house. I was Papa's "Assistant Adjutant" on the trip and was kept so busy

that I wrote but few letters - one each to "Uncle John" and "Aunt Louisa" at Jacksonville and the others to Mama. Lieutenant Beck was Adjutant. He drew the pay and took most of the glory. I did the work i.e. a large share of it. I'm glad I was useful and I wouldn't have missed the trip for anything. We returned Sept.16th. The last part of the trip we traveled two nights right straight ahead, and for a week afterward I worked all day and till after midnight, helping Papa about his official report. Naturally I haven't felt much like writing letters - this being my first attempt - and I hope you will pardon my delay. I saw so much and went to so many places while on the expedition, that it would take a volume to give an account of my travels and experiences. I kept my journal as regularly as possible. Well I have been in an Indian fight, and as the officers term it, have "smelt powder". It is

exciting to hear the volleys and to hear the rifleballs sing. I feel like an old soldier.
Robert

Fort Concho Texas
Thursday, Oct. 21st. 1880
My dear Bessie.
It hardly seems possible that over four months have gone since I came away from Jacksonville! I meant to write long ago but many things prevented. I arrived June 21st taking the folks by surprise & July10th left with my father for the wilderness "on the warpath". I did not know I would go on the scout till shortly before we went. Soon after getting here I wrote a good many letters and intended to write to you

Around Fort Concho the country consists mostly of prairie covered by good grass and crossed by belts of mesquite timber. A good many cattle and sheep are raised about here. The mesquite trees look like an apple orchard at a distance. The Conchos are beautiful streams. The soil is generally good but owing to the dryness of the climate the bottom land along the streams only is cultivated and by irrigation. Large pecan and oak trees grow along the streams. Fifteen miles to the north are a range of high hills & 6 miles to the west are another range & the Twin Mountains. Cedar and live oaks grow in the hills to the north & at the heads of the streams. The country has settled a good deal in the last two years. The town of San Angelo just a mile north of the post on the other side of the creek has grown so that I hardly new it . they publish a paper there. Ben Ficklin 3 mi. south, the county-seat of "Tom Green Country" has also grown

These towns & in fact all of the towns of western Texas are mostly built of adobe. The country about Fort Stockton is very different. There is no timber & hardly any grass. The whole surface of the country is covered with low brush dwarf mesquite, Spanish bayonets & other worthless vegetation. The Pecos between here and Stockton is the strangest stream I ever saw. There are no trees along the banks & the water is a red - brown. They burn mesquite roots for fuel & measure them by the pound. It is so dry that it takes a big root to collect sufficient moisture to support a small bush. Fort Davis - still further west - is quite. The scenery about in the Apache mts. is picturesque. The live oaks on the mountain side & in places in the valleys, the rugged mountains and meadow like grass in the valleys make a pretty picture. If there was only plenty of water it would be a valuable country.

The scenery in Limpia canyons? & Musques? near Davis is fine. Great walls of rock hundreds of feet high in places rise on both sides of the road. 35 miles west? of Davis the country is an elevated plateau plain from 5000 to nearly 7000 ft above the sea, crossed by ranges of almost in accessible mounts. The Guadalupes are the highest point in Texas. Its summit is nearly over 3000 ft above the level of the plain & nearly 10000 ft above he sea. in '78 I was on top of this mountain. The view was perfectly grand. The valleys between the mountains are in some places covered with good grass but in most places are covered with immense Spanish bayonets - some of which are 20 or 30 feet high, many varieties of cacti and other thorny sawedged plants and entangling

and a luxurious growth of sawedged plants and grasses and thorny and entangling bushes of all descriptions. Both of our engagements with the Indians were in places of this character. The valley between the Sierra Diablo & Devilshoof Mountains is certainly a diabolical place. I presume Rattlesnake Spring is so named because it would kill a rattlesnake to drink much of it. The water is strongly impregnated with gypsum. There are a number of salt lakes in that vicinity. In spite of the desolateness there are some very pretty sights. The clouds often are beautiful & often the tops of the mountains are covered with & it is a pretty sight to see the top of the mountains towering above the clouds. The sun rises and the sunsets are very fine. The air is very clear & mirages are often seen. The stars and moon seem to shine brighter. On a clear day glare of the sun is almost blinding. The morning we left Rattlesnake Spring the reflection of the mountains in the mirror like salt lake was one of the beautiful sights I ever saw.

The El Paso
A trip to El Paso after seeing such worthless country is an agreeable change. El Paso & the narrow strip extending about 30m along the Rio Grande is an oasis in the desert of Northern Mexico & Western Texas. The soil is very rich and grain, vegatables and the most delicious fruits are raised by irrigation. We were there the first of September just in the fruit season. How we enjoyed the grapes, pears, peaches, apples, and melons! It was such a change from canned stuff & bacon. The El Paso grapes are large black and very sweet and make good wine. White grapes are also grown. The El Paso onions have a great reputation. They are so mild that a fellow could safely eat one and then go calling. The Mexicans are a strange people. They use the same kind of farming implements that were used in the year 1. Their carts and wagons are a curiosity - made entirely of wood

In one respect the Mexicans (in the towns) are like cottontail rabbits; they are out in the mornings & evenings but like to stay above unclear under cover during the day. The rainfall at Coucho (all over W.T. for that matter) this year has been unusually heavy so that the duck shooting is splendid this fall. I have been very successful. One afternoon I killed 45 nearly all on the wing. Harry & George are pretty good shots. Lieut. Davis is an excellent shot. On one day Harry & I killed 91? ducks which we got -  a good many others floated off. Last of the week on another hunt we killed 93. The of the ducks so far are mostly teal but large mallards spoonbills & other large ducks

There is little much game in "those parts". In places there is not enough grass for miles to feed a jackrabbit. Coyotes horned toads & a great variety of lizards are the principal inhabitants. Now & then you meet a terrapin. Deer are found in some of the mountains but as we were after Indians there was little time to hunt. Some places there are Tarantulas?,centipedes, scorpions & myriads of yellow butterflies and grasshoppers so big and fat that they can't fly and when they jump they never (hardly ever) lie? right side up. At the salt marshes the mosquitoes well one of 'em equals a half doden ordinary ones. Along the Rio Grande there there are the queerest kind of bugs - one kind looks like a camel (not so large however.)

Major: I have to thank you for the very efficient and ready attention you have given all my wishes in regard to my new duties. It appears now that all the Kiowas and Comanches will be in and my work here will be very responsible and arduous and if you will permit Capt. Old Agency Sept. 10, 1872
Hon Enoch Hoag 
Dear Sir: On the 8th inst. we had a proposition made to us by General Grierson Commander at Fort Gibson that we were requested to meet Chief Chicote and his men in Council twelve in number as a committee on their side and the same number on our side to meet at the Agency on the 9th inst. We accepted the proposition and went with our committee at the time appointed. The General requested that we should go in a spirit of peace and harmony and try to have an amicable settlement of our difficulty. The General told us when he made us the proposition that Chief Checote said he was only after horsethieves and not after or aiming at distressing the people. We went in the spirit suggested to us by the General and met said Committee, Miccohutkee being chairman of the Committee. After we met said committee of Chief Chicote's men the chief made a speech to the same purport of the information conveyed to us by General Grierson and then turned and went out. After Chief Chicote concluded his speech Chief Lochorhays on our side made a few remarks to the same purport and we were then ready for business. But instead of meeting us in the spirit of fairness and manliness as the speeches and propositions would indicate we had a paper presented to us for our signatures which we were required to sign under oath which set forth that we must not hold or give countenance to any Council or political meeting or gathering of any sort except what was provided for in the Constitution of this Nation

and upon condition of signing said paper we would be allowed to go to our homes in peace but not otherwise. We wish now to say that we accepted then proposition sent to us by the Commanding General in good faith, and when we professed to meet our brethren in terms of honor and fairness we meant it and we at all times mean what we say. But we do not mean to sign any such paper. We demand our treaty rights and we mean to have them. We are not culprits. We are freemen and fought for our rights and our rights are all we ask. We wish also to say that we desire to go home in peace as duties at home require our presence. We agree to be subject to the laws that are now in force in this Nation and ask protection under them until the decision of the late investigation by Superintendent Hoag. Excepting the laws enacted at the late Council at Okmulkee [[Okmulgee?}}. But we shall sign no paper now. We shall wait and abide by the decision of the recent investigation concluded by Supt. Hoag, and Mr. Campbell of St. Louis at the Creek Agency in July last. 
Respectfully submitted

Head Quarters Dist. Indian Territory
Chief Quartermaster's Office
Fort Gibson C.N. , January 11th 1869.
Brevet Major General L. C. Easton,
Deputy Qr. Mr. General Chief Qr. Mr. Dept. of the Ms.
Fort Leavenworth Kansas
General: 

            I have delayed replying to your letter of December 12, 1868, that I might avail myself of all information possible by which I might indicate what seems the best, most expeditious and economical course to be pursued with reference to supplying this district for the coming fiscal year.

I … In answer to your question I would say via Arkansas River and Fort Gibson or Fort Smith. I will give my reasons later.
II … I am satisfied from the evidence that has been laid before me that either of the three steamers (each 250 tons burthen) hereafter mentioned can reach Gibson whenever they can reach Smith.
III … I do not know the exact distance from Smith to Cobb. From Gibson to Cobb (via Arbuckle) by odometer measurement it is 276 miles. (Please consult Genl. Merrill's map of the Indian Territory of June 28, 1867) From Smith it is probably forty miles further. From Gibson to Cobb via Kickapoo-Town or Seminole Agency it is nearly 230 miles

IV … I would invite your attention to General Grierson's report to Dept. Head Quarters of his expedition last summer, dated July 14, 1898 and doubtless on file in Gen. McKeevers office. 
V … Four  scouts (all exceedingly intelligent and observing men) who accompanied Genl. Sheridan to Fort Cobb, and who were sent home via Seminole and Kickapootown, give unanimous and emphatic evidence in favor of supplying Fort Cobb and vicinity via Gibson if the river can be depended upon.
VI... Capt. Bennett (of the "Fort Smith") who has navigated the Arkansas River for 35 years gives this testimony: "With the Steamers Fort Smith, Fort Gibson and Van Buren (all with draft of ten (10) inches empty and with a draft of 3 feet loaded) with lighters, I say deliberately that 2000000 lbs. can be placed at Gibson at any season of the year (except July and August) at 40 days notice."
VII … I have unofficial information that a new six Company Cavalry post is to be established at or near Washita village longitude 98 (See Genl. Grierson's Report) as well as official information from Genl. Grierson that the force in the District "is to be largely increased" (Please see my estimate for C.C.S.G.E. on account of Cavalry.)
VIII … The facilities at Fort Gibson as a Depot should not be overlooked. I have good stables (erected the past Summer)to accommodate 600 mules. The country is rich and fertile, well wooded &

and watered. Regular supplies of the Quartermasters Department contracted for are cheap. (Please see my contracts) I have storehouses and forage houses of ample capacity to accommodate the wants of the Depot. To sum up I would say:
First: that with the information in my possession at present this District can be completely and thoroughly and most cheaply supplied from this point.
Second: That the supplies of every post should be laid down unclear for at least four (4) months in advance.
Third: That the roads are good and made from here to Fort Cobb.
Fourth: That all of the streams are fordable for at least eight months in the year.
Fifth: That I have my superintendent with mechanics and laborers now on the road providing permanent bridges, rafts, boats and for crossing the Deep Fork, North Fork of the Canadian arm of Little River (see Genl. Merrill) map.  
Finally I would respectfully & deliberately recommend that all posts established (or to be established) in this District, East unclear of the Antelope Hills, Longitude 
100° and Latitude 36° be supplied via the Arkansas River and this Depot, provided that supplies & adequate transportation therefor, for four months in advance, for each post can be obtained at this Depot. I propose to advertise immediately (until Febry 1,1869) for 2000000 pounds of transportation for this District for the year  (over)

commencing April 1,1869. My annual estimate for this District on account of the Quartermasters Department so far as I am at present officially acquainted with it will be forwarded in a few days.
Very respectfully
Your unclear
(signed) H.F. Rockwell

the Spring, and imagined, that to the astonishment of Mr. [?Lo?] Esq, it might yet become the squatting place of Some enterprising Yankee and have many visitors to it as a noted watering place.
Passing on to Cabin Creek we camped,   Estimating the march at 33 miles.
Saturday May 2".    Came from Cabin Creek to Tryons Creek, 20 miles, camped near the residence of Mrs. Alberti.  Beautiful day and evening, and decidedly the prettiest and neatest camp recently established on this rout [sic].  Several Cherokees Called at Camp, and the band gave a grand Serenade for the Natives.  Good Spring near the Camp.  The General is Constantly in good heart and kind to all.

4.
Sunday May 3"  Marched 20 miles & camped at "14 mile creek.  Crossed Flat Rock Creek.
Monday May 4.  Passing over Some very bad road we arrived about noon at Fort Gibson, meeting with a kind reception from Captaincies and Mrs. Alvord.

     The entire march was pleasant and without accident.

Journal Of The Expedition of the Wichita Mountains
Left Ft. Gibson O.K. about noon on the 1st of June. Moved westward, crossed the Arkansas river on a ferry at the mouth of the unclear. Passed Old Fort Davis, a Small earth work constructed during the war, and halted for the night at the Agency of the Creek Indians few miles West of St. Gibson. General Grierson remained in Ft. Gibson until the next morning to await the arrival of an Odometer, which had been sent by express from St. Louis, to enable us to measure the distance on our march.
On the morning of the 2" we broke camp at daylight and marched thirty two miles, encamping at 2 P.M on the Second crossing of Cane Creek. Here we were joined by the General at 5 o'clock P.M. The day was very warm and after the fatiguing march across the praireie through the broiling

Sun, we enjoyed our bivouac very much in the shade of the trees on the banks of the beautiful little rocky stream. On the 3" we marched thirty five miles and encamped on Owl Creek naming our camp "Black Snake" after a huge reptile of that species which I killed directly after we halted. It was six feet long and nearly as thick as an ordinary spirit bottle.
On the 4" we marched to Tiger Creek and halted on a rocky hill overlooking this stream, naming our camp "Tarantula?" from the fact of our having caught alive, and caged one of these desperate and dangerous little animals. Here we carried on quite a trade with a party of Creek Indians who came into our camp with fresh vegetables, birds and chickens. This tribe are quite numerous. They are semi-civilized and entirely self sustaining. They are at peace with all the other tribes and with the United States.
On the 5" we marched to the Seminole Agency, thence S. W. encamping on a Limestone Bluff two miles South of Kettle River, a very charming camp on account of the beautiful cool spring which gushed from the hill sides in every direction. During the night a

furious rain storm visited us.
On the 6th we continued our course S.W. to the Canadian river. This is a wide, shallow stream, the entire bed consisting of quicksand bars. We found it swolen with recent heavy rains and the usual ford washed out until it was fifteen or twenty feet deep. Not wishing to be be detained in our march until the river should subside, we explored the chanel by riding in horses and feeling about for the shallow places until we succeeded in finding a new crossing which we improved by cutting away the trees and digging down the bank so as to make the approach easy for wagons. By four? o'clock P.M. we were comfortably in camp on the South bank, having made but 13 miles. This Canadian river is a very long stream, one of the main branches of the Arkansas. It is easily crossed at almost any point if one keeps moving, but the moment you halt the sand gives way and you commence to sink. It is the boundary between the Creek and Chickasaw nations at the point where we crossed and we now found ourselves facing this latter people.

They are not very numerous and like the Creeks, Choctaws, Cherokees and Seminoles are semi-civilized and generally self-sustaining, raising cattle, corn and garden vegetables. From our camp on the Canadian we witnessed one of the most glorious Sunsets imaginable. Indeed nothing can exceed in splendor the Sunsets generally in this Country. Methinks Italy would tremble for her laurels in this particular if she were brought into comparison with the Indian Territory.
The Country is generally rolling prairie with but little timber and this generally distributed along the water courses, so that the view from the hill tops is unobstructed.
On the 7" we moved out at daylight and kept our course of S.W. crossing the Ouachita river, and two miles South of it, Rush Creek. The Ouachita is a swift running muddy stream, a branch of the Red River. The water is a chrome yellow and imparts its color to every thing with which it comes in contact.

I imagine the tidy housewifes of the States would not fancy it for washing their fine snowy linens! this was the thought which struch me when I saw a towel which was washed in it. Rush Creek, a branch of the Oachita is a narrow, high bank, muddy stream with a very boggy ford and it was with much difficulty that we succeeded in crossing the animals and wagons safely. Night overtook us before the train had crossed and we desisted until morning.
It had rained very hard during the day and we were muddy and wet, but having crossed to the South Side before dark, I prefered sleeping in my wet clothes upon a wet saddle blanket with the canopy of heaven for a covering, to risking the chances of re-crossing safely in the dark to our tents and baggage which were on the North Side.
On the 8" we continued our march, making eighteen miles and reaching Fort Arbuckle about 3 o'clk P.M. The band, which accompanied us, struck up a lively

air, heralding our approach, and the Garrison, consisting of four companies of Cavalry + two of Infantry turned out en masse to receive us.
Fort Arbuckle is built up on a level plateau almost surrounded by high hills and is chiefly attractive on account of a magnificent spring of immense capacity which supplies the entire garrison with elegant waters. It is an old post abandoned during the war and Since un-occupied. It is, at present the extreme outpost on this line. The Country over which we have thus far passed between here and Ft. Gibson is sparsely settled by the Indian Tribes I have mentioned. They generally select for their abodes secluded places along the water courses away from the highroads and lines of travel of the white man.
They live in rudely Constructed log huts and are filthy in the extreme. Very few of them speak English and it is with the greatest reluctance that they can be prevailed upon to do so,

when they have this ability.
Before the war, they, like our southern, in the older parts of the states, held the negroes in bondage. Many of these still remain among them and are by far the most useful and thrifty portion of the community.
We remained at Ft. Arbuckle until noon on the 11th, when, having our little escort reenforced by a detachment of four Hundred of the 10" Cav, and     [ ? ] Infantry of the 6" Regiment which we used as a train guard, we again took the prairie, Westward bound.

     We now traveled entirely by the map and compass without reference to roads.  We marched this afternoon about five miles, fording Wildhorse Creek & encamping on a pond, which by common consent, we named "Snake Pond." from the fact that a large snake came dropping out of one of the trees over our heads and ran off into the water, and from the general Snaky appearance which the pond presented.

difficult on account of he numerous small streams (boggy) which crossed our path and which we were compeled [sic] to bridge in order to cross our little train of thirty wagons.  During the day we ascended to another peak of the Table mountains, from which we Saw in the distance, a large herd of wild cattle.  These generally roam unmolested over the vast grassy plains of which the Country Consists and at this Season of the year are exceedingly [?flat?] and fine for beef.  We encamped this evening upon the hills adjoining the Table mountains.  This we named Camp "Belleview" in remembrance of the magnificent view which spread out before us. 

   June 14" we moved over the hills about Seven miles, thence into the valley of Rush Creek, bridged three Small Streams and corduroyed a Swamp for Some distance.  I captured a beautiful little fawn during the day and carried it about a mile in my arms, but having no proper food

for it and no hope of raising it with much success, I set it at liberty.  These are certainly the emblem of innocence and purity.  This morning an immense Rattlesnake was killed, at least six feet long and very thick.  I secured the rattles, fifteen in number.  We encamped at 5 o’clk P.M. on a rocky hill overlooking the valley of Rush Creek & named our camp “Pleasant Plain” after an idea of Dr. Hubbard (one of our party) for I don’t think the rest of us saw anything very pleasant about it.  The Caddoes came in at dusk, with a deer and wild turkey.  Venison for breakfast, turkey for lunch.  On the 15” we continued our march Westward, crossing numerous small branches of Rush Creek, one of which had a solid rocky bed with a delicate little cataract at the crossing area just below it an excavation made in the solid rocky by the constant dripping and running of this water, forming a beautiful pool or bath, the water clear as crystal and containing many delicate little gold fish.  It was so inviting to pass unheeded and

we halted a couple hours to bathe in the clear limpid water.  We then moved on & encamped in the prairie on the banks of the headwaters of Rush Creek.  On the 16” we traveled about nineteen miles, mostly through poor, sandy, Shinook country, passed the site of an old village of the Wichita Indians. Area the scene of an engagement with the Indians by Gen. Van Donn some years ago.  I called for an hour by the side of the Wichita Spring, the source of the Ruch Creek, which furnishes an abundance of clear cool water, winding our way over the barren hills, scaring up herds of deer and antelope at almost every turn, about 10 A.M. obtaining the first view of Mt. Scott, the highest peak of the Wichita Mts. looming up thirty miles away, and encamped at 5 o’clk P.M. on the headwaters of the Ouachita River.  As I was riding with Captain Walsh in the morning his horse jumped over something beneath us gave a pitiful bleat, looking down was a young fawn in the grass, His horse had stepped upon it.  With characteristic kindness the Captain dismounted and carried

this little animal beyond the reach of harm from the column which follows us.  During the day a nest of young eagles was captured.  June 17” we marched at 5 A.M. and during the day crossed seven branches of the Little Ouachitas all with very high, steep banks, hard to approach.  We were compeled to build crossings over all of them.  These streams are all so brackish with Gypsum that it is almost impossible to drink the waters.  The country abounds in deer, antelope and other game.  By 3 o’clk P.M. we had crossed the last of these streams & encamped on the South Side. This we named Camp Gypsum from the prevalence of the mineral and the condition of the water which is impregnated with it.  We obtained some fine specimens.  The command having encamped, with one man and an Indian I continued on our intended course to explore as far as possible the line of March for the next morning.  I proceeded about five miles over the rolling plains directly toward Mt. Scott.

The entire range of the Wichita Mountains are now in full view, although still probably 30 miles away.  Got a long range shot at a wolf, saw horned toads and numerous indications of Rattlesnakes which abound in these prairies.  I returned to camp at 0 o’clk P.M. thoroughly worn out with my day’s work.  On the 18” we marched at 5 A.M. in an air line for Mt. Scott, passed through a vast prairie dog town, these lively, interesting little animals sitting upon the edge of their holes, barking as we passed. They are about the size and very much resemble a squirrel.  The Indians eat them. About noon we encamped on a beautiful rocky branch of Cache Creek about eight miles N.E. of the base of Mt. Scott.  After encamping, a party of us accompanied the General upon a visit to the hills adjacent to the mountains and obtained some beautiful views up & down the valley of Cache Creek.  On the 19” we left the command in camp at this point, and a small party consisting of

Gen. Grierson, Captain Walsh & Alvord, Dr. Hubbard and myself with an escort of fifteen men and one days rations, started to explore Mt. Scott.  On the way we saw much game such as deer, antelope, wolf, turkey ec.  I chased down and killed a large wolf.  We searched the base of the mountains at 7 1/2 A.M. and immediately commenced the ascent on foot.  After about three hours extremely hard and dangerous climbing we reached the Summit about 1100 feet above the level of the plain below.  It is a very Rocky Mountain and as you approach the Summit the rocks become larger and more detached, piled up promiscuously forming immense caverns which are doubtless inhabited by bear, panther and other large game. We saw numerous indications of these from the beaten paths over the rocks and among the bushes.  The Indian guides that accompanied us stated that they often came there to hunt bear.  During the ascent we regaled ourselves with an abundance

of raspberries and wild currants which grow upon the mountain side.  Immediately upon reaching the Summit we killed an immense Rattlesnake of which I secured the rattles and the fangs.  After taking notes and sketches of the surrounding country, which was placed before us in every direction as far as the eye could reach, we partook of a lunch, deposited a few lines in a bottle which we secured in the rocks, and leaving other evidences of our visit for this information and edification of curious travellers who may follow us in after years, we descended, reaching the base about one o’clk P.M.  The party became considerably scattered in the descent, and for a time we feared several men lost; finally we collected the entire party, mounted and returned to camp, arriving about 0 o’clk P.M. feeling sufficiently unclear for the day.  It is needless to say that we rested well tonight.  This camp we named Camp Ranch after the remains of an old ranch formerly kept here by a white man named Chandler who

herded cattle and traded with the Indians.  We see every sign of immense herds of Buffalo which have moved through here a few weeks earlier in the season.  On returning to camp this evening we found “Tochawa” the chief of the Peneteghkes or Honeyeaters a friendly band of the Comanches.  He comes in acceptance of an invitation of the General to accompany us on the March and became our guide.  He is a jolly old Dove and enjoys  the white man’s fare amazingly.  One wife accompanied him, the most disgusting specimen of female humanity I ever witnessed.  Like the red man’s wife generally, she is more servant than wife, pitching his tent, sadling his horses and doing all the drudgery of the establishment.  
June 20” we moved camp at 7 a.m. South eight miles to the junction of a beautiful branch of Cache Creek with the main stream and near the Scrap Rock bluffs, called by the Indians “Medicine Bluffs” one account of their supposed medicinal qualities.

These wild aboriginal creatures go there to sleep when they are unwell, with the faith that this simple act alone will restore them to health.  This is one of the most picturesque spots I have ever beheld.  The bluffs ascend gradually on one Side and Suddenly drop off on the other in a perpendicular precipice three hundred feet to the bed of a beautiful stream formed from Mountain Springs.  The view from the elevation is perfectly grand.  The Indians have many stories connected with these bluffs.  One of which is, that a young warrior vainly in love with an Indian maiden rode to the Summit, put spurs to his horse and dashed headlong over the precipice putting an end to his miserable existence.
While riding round to Select a camp for the command I had a spirited chase after a fine buck, but he escaped me.  Soon after, one of the Indian guides brought him in.   At the Southern base of the Medicine Bluffs are found numerous fine springs, among them

several salt springs.

   This evening four Wichita Indians with interpreters joined us as guides.  They are much [?amused?] by the band which each evening discourses Sweet music for our benefit.

    The Command remained in Camp here Six days during which Time we made a thorough exploration of the Surrounding Country.

    On the 21" under the guidance of "Tochana" we rode five miles Eastward to See the Tar springs, found the pure article oozing from the ground on the Top of a hill with every indication of a splendid quality of coal.  The hills in the vicinity are evidently Solid beds of coal.  Having Secured fine Specimens of the tar and coal we returned to Camp.

  The beautiful stream which [?winds?] along at the foot of our camp we have named -  "Medicine Bluffs Creek".

On the 22d we Sent Such wagons as were empty and could be spared from the train, with a small escort back to Ft. Arbuckle.  Gen. Grierson accompanied the expedition as as [sic] far as the Wichita Springs for the purpose of examining the route, leaving me with orders to explore the Country in the vicinity and south of our present camp, during his absence.

  In the afternoon Dr. Hubbard and myself again visited the Medicine Bluffs for the purpose of sketching the surrounding country.  Indeed, after the [ ? ] , this is the most fascinating spot has been my good fortune to visit and I could willingly have taken up a permanent abode here.   A heavy shower coming up, we returned to camp.

 During the day I found a very fine pair of antlers which had but a short time since decorated the head of some unfortunate buck. 

 The climate here seems to be delightfully healthy, a fine breeze always prevailing, So that though the sun may be powerful, one does not realize that it is so warm.

On the following morning, June 23." Dr. Hubbard, Lt. Jacobs of the 6" Int. & myself with a detachment of ten men and two Indian guides proceeded S.E. along Cache Creek to examine the Country.  Found game, especially deer very plenty and had Several unsuccessful chases.

 About 11 o'clock A.M. we discovered a few Buffalo in the distance.  We approached them gradually as they passed over a hill to the West and upon gaining the Top of the hill a Sight presented itself which, I must confess, for a time inspired me with awe.  

  In the valley beneath, and within easy rifle range, quietly grazing, was a herd too numerous to mention or estimate, but certainly ten thousand would not be an exaggeration.  To refrain the men from the chase was a thing impossible.  Deploying them so as to avoid the danger of their Shooting each other in the excitement we sailed into the herd, which by

this Time had become alarmed and was one vast, black, moving mass, making the earth tremble as they ran.  My pen is powerless to portray the wild exciting Scene which ensued.  The excitement of the men was only exceeded by that of the horses and it was with great difficulty that I restrained my own charger from dashing into the midst of the herd to become gored and trampled under foot.  One horse threw his rider and ran off into the herd and another in clearing a ditch turned a Summersault [?...ing?]  his rider headlong before him, but the horses were recovered and nobody hurt.
Having brought down two immense bulls myself and feeling Satisfied that the horseflesh had been sufficiently taxed, I rallied the men and found that we had killed Six very large animals and captured a calf alive.

We were now fifteen miles from camp and it was just noon.  Dispatching a couple of couriers to the camp for wagons to take in the meat, with the rest of the force we proceeded to dress and cut up the animals.   Soon after the couriers Started, the Dr. also returned to camp in order to hurry on the wagons.  As night approached we looked anxiously for them but no wagons came.   We had killed the Bufalo in radius of two miles and the meat being too bulky to carry to one point I was obliged to divide my little force into five parts and scatter them in order to protect the meat from the depredations of the ravenous wolves and buzzards.
We were now in the midst of a vast prairie with no wood in sight and no water within a mile and that miserable stuff from a Buffalo wallow through which the vast herd had run during the day.   This in addition to the fact that we had nothing to

eat but raw Buffalo meat and no blankets formed our prospect for an all night in the prairie.  We fired signal guns at intervals till long after dark to guide the wagons should they be in our vicinity.  Having disposed of the men So as to guard all the meat, it left Lt. Jacobs, one of the Indians (the other having separated from us during the day) as guard to one lot.
Unsadling our horses and holding them by the bridle in order that they might graze around us and not escape, for there was not even a bush to hitch them to, we laid down for rest, lulled to slumber by the fierce baying of the wolves which surrounded us on all Sides, but at a respectful distance, attracted by the carcases.
Thus we passed, uneasily, the night continually startled by the Snorting and jumping of the horses, as Some wolf more bold than the rest approached us.
At daylight the next morning, June 24" I started another courier for wagons, determined to await their arrival until the

the last minute in order to save the large amount of meat which was so much needed by the command.
Thus we patiently waited until 11 o'clk this morning when, no wagons being in sight from the adjacent hill tops, and feeling keenly the gnawings of hunger, I determined to abandon the meat at least 5000 pds and started for camp.  We attempted to take the calf along, but soon the little fellow became tired and stubborn, and lying down, we were compeled [sic] to turn him loose.

 We reached camp about [?] o'clk P.M. having had nothing to eat Since early morning of the day before.  We found that wagons had been Sent out immediately upon the arrival of the couriers the day before, but in the vast prairie the guides had lost the way and could not find us.   They too remained out all night, and the next morning giving up all hope of finding us, and running across

some Buffalo, they killed two and returned to camp.  This was my first Buffalo chase, and I must confess I felt considerably elated over our Success, although much chagrined over our inability to save the meat.
During these two days our little party killed six rattlesnakes, two of which I dispatched myself.  These prairies abound with them.
Simultaneously with our return to camp, Gen Grierson arrived from the Wichita Springs, after an absence of three days.
On the 25" we remained in camp at Medicine Bluffs and I [?improved?] the opportunity to rest myself and horses after the fatiguing work of the last Sixty hours.

  On the 26" the command moved camp at 6 o'clk A.M. marched fifteen miles S.W. along the base of the mountains and encamped in a beautiful oak grove on West Cache Creek at a point where it enters to mountains.  On this side the

mountains are very rugged, being generally huge piles of rocks, almost  barren of vegetation and presenting a very strange appearance.

 This West  branch of Cache Creek is a clear, swift running mountain stream and we enjoyed bathing in it very much.

 The weather now is excessively warm & were it not for the breeze which prevails would be almost unbearable.

  On the 27" the command remain in camp all day at this point.  Gen. Grierson with a small party went on an exploring expedition to the South and Capt. Alvord, Dr. Hubbard and myself with a small escort and the Indians went upon a hunting expedition to obtain fresh meat for the Command.  We went S.E,  crossed the West Cache Creek, and about Seven miles from camp found plenty of Buffalo.  This time we took wagons so as to be sure of the means to bring in the results of our hunting.    By 11 o'clk we had killed four large animals, which being sufficient, we returned to camp.

During the day we saw large herds of deer and antelope and killed one rattlesnake.

  On the 28" we marched at 5 o'clk A.M. West by Southwest toward old camp [?Rodjaninsky?] making about twenty miles and encamping on Otter Creek about two miles from the Sight of this old camp.

A number of years ago this was occupied by United States troops under Gen. Van Dorn during a winter campaign against the Comanche Indians.  The ruins are still quite visible.  It is named in honor of an officer of his command Lt. [?Rodjaninsky?] who died about the time the camp was established.   During the day we have seen vast herds of Buffalo and a couple have been killed for fresh meat.  For the last ten days we have Subsisted almost entirely upon Buffalo and venison.
The prairie dogs and their [?homes?[ are quite an interesting feature of this country covering thousands of acres.  They burrow deeply into the ground and in riding through them one has to be very careful

lest his horse step into these holes breaking his own legs and his rider's neck.

  The Mesquit trees are also a peculiarity.  We are now in a vast forest of them.  Their greatest Size is that of an ordinary peach tree, the wood is very hard and only valuable for wood-fuel.  They bear a kind of bean which when matured is good for stock.  The Indians also rise [sic] them, making a kind of panola or bread of them.

In some localities, especially in Texas and Mexico this Mesquit growth does not obtain a greater height than eighteen inches or two feet but intertwines its branches until it becomes impenetrable and forms the celebrated [?chappane?] of those countries  The Mesquit and Buffalo grasses also prevail here.  These grow very short but are exceedingly rich and nutritious.  Horses will keep in splendid order [?nine?] months in the year without any grain.

8
On the 29" General Grierson with a small detachment went to Camp [?Rodjaminsky?], thence South to Red River.  With the main column and the train I moved N.E. through a gap in the mountains toward Ft. Cobb, making only ten miles in order that the General might return and overtake us before night.   Today we have been Surrounded by thousands of Buffalo.  The Country is litterally [sic] black with them.  I could not refrain from another chase and in half an hour had killed a fine bull and a calf.  Several more were killed by the command, and Several calves were captured alive.

  About 10" o'clk A.M. we met a party of about one hundred Indians, mostly Comanches.  They were on the war path in Search of the remains of some of their tribe who are Supposed to have been murdered by the Navajoes between whom and the Comanches there is a deadly feud.  The Navajoes but a short time Since made a raid on the Comanches

and captured Several hundred head of their horses and this party intend to revenge the outrage.  There are Several chiefs among them, the most noted being [?Asbobat?], the war chief to the [?Peneleghkes?], a stern looking warrior who is never seen to smile.   This party are in their war costume which consists of almost nothing but paint and trinkets.  They are armed generally with bows, arrows, lances, and Shields and a few have rifles and pistols.  They approached us very friendly and encamped with us until the morrow.  They had not a thing to eat, depending entirely upon hunting, meat being their only article of food.  Having a Surplus I issued to them some flour and coffee.  They were much interested by the music of the band which played at Sunset and in the evening, they, upon their Side, had a general war dance.  This was one of the most interesting and attractive Sights I have ever witnessed.  Painted

from head to foot in the most fantastic manner, decked in gaudy head dresses composed of horns, feathers, [?] and with their shields, lances and quivers ornamented with feathers of the liveliest here dancing around a large bonfire chanting a mournful tune to the still more mournful music of the Tom Tom, while, at intervals the chief                 [?Asolabet]? would dash into the ring upon his white horse and exhort them to be brave warriors and acquit themselves honorably in the coming conflict.   All this in language which had been Greek to us except for the presence of our very clever and intelligent interpreter, Mr. Jones, altogether was a [?wild?] patriotic Sight, which language cannot describe.

  Our camp here is a pleasant one, except that we are compeled [sic] to drink water from standing pools in which the Buffalo have wallowed.

  The nights now are beautifully moonlight, and the effect upon these vast prairies with the glowing camp fires and the dim outline of the mountains discernible in

the distance is truly inspiring.

   June 30" being the end of the month the troops are inspected & mustered for pay although need not expect to see the jovial countenance of the Paymaster until our return to the vicinity of civilization.  We part company with the Indians this morning & by invitation Several of the chiefs took breakfast with us, among them [?Tochawa?]     [?Asolabet?] and [?Queenababet?] of the Comanches.    Table [?man?] did not seem to be a necessity for their enjoyment of the meal and with the exception of Tochawa who has associated with the white man more than the others, they acted on the principle that fingers were made before forks.

  After the repast Asolabet washed it down with a draught from my wash basin which Stood upon a box behind him, unemptied after my morning ablutions.

  After breakfast with many assurances of friendship they took leave of us going S.W. to hunt the remains of

their murdered braves and Seek revenge upon their murderers, while we continued on our course in a N. easterly direction toward the Washita river, making Twenty five miles and encamping upon a beautiful branch of Cache Creek.

  July 1"  we marched at [?] o'clk A.M. N.E. and encamped at 11 A.M. on the banks of the Washita in Ureka Valley, so named by Col. Leavenworth, the Agent of the Comanches and Kiowas who has established his agency on the hillside upon the opposite side of the river and whose Hd. Qrs. we visited in the Afternoon.  The Caddoes also have their lodges in this valley and until recently the Wichitas, Wacos, & [?Tochanas?] [? born?] of the Comanches, all friendly bands, also lived here in a state of semi-civilization cultivating little patches of corn & raising cattle, but since the late incursion of the Navajoes they became frightened & moved

about  six miles further East down the Washita to Cottonwood grove.  This morning Gen Grierson with a small escort left the main column and went farther West to visit the site of Old Fort Cobb.  He found this quite an interesting locality and the remains of the old quarters still in a tolerably good state of preservation.  He rejoined us soon after we had encamped.   Near Cottonwood Grove we struck the old road from Fort Arbuckle to Ft. Cobb and having no further use for guides they were paid and dismissed.

 July 2nd" we moved down the Washita [?calling?] for an hour at Cotton Wood Grove among the Indian villages, where we amused the inhabitants with the music of the band.  At this point there are several trading ranches carried on by white men.   Here we met "Horseback" one of the most noted & cruel of the Comanche chiefs.  Nude [?] waist and painted bright red, he presented

a wild and desperate appearance.  His daughter was one of the most comely Indian maidens of the wild tribes that I have met.  She was gorgeously attired in bright colors and trinkets and sat astride her horse as only these queens of the forest can do.  These Comanches are splendid riders, seeming when on horseback to be a part of the animal.  In the chase they seldom use a saddle.  After seeing everything of interest we proceeded on our march making twenty three miles and encamped on the Little Oachita near its junction with the main stream.  Here we found the lodges of a small band of the Delawares who are about one degree farther advanced in civilization than the bands we left this morning, but they have the same filthy habits as the rest.

 On the 3rd we marched at 4 A.M. found the beautiful Elm Spring on the banks of the Washita & encamped in the Kickapoo flats, making thirty miles.

 July 4, the anniversary of our

nation's independence we marched at half past Four o'clk A.M. crossed Rush and Wild Horse Creeks at fords and reached Ft. Arbuckle at noon, in the midst of the firing of the National Salute.

   Our return today was a little unexpected to the garrison but we were not any the less [?con...sily?] received by the officers and their ladies who had been entertained for Several days past with wild reports of our engagement with, and defeat by, the Indians with heavy loss.

  July 5th being Sunday we spent in quarters and in paying our respects to the officers and their families at Ft. Arbuckle.  On the 6th, having dismissed such portion of our escort as belonged to the garrison at Fort Arbuckle, with our own little Hd Qrs' detachment of 15 men, at 2 o'clk P.M. we took the road for Fort Gibson.

  The General was determined to make a bee line for our destination regardless of roads, fording

the Washita at a point four miles from Fort Arbuckle we struck [? into th..?] prairie going [?] N.W. and encamped on a Small Stream ten miles out.

   July 7" we marched at 6 o'clk A.M. through woods and prairie and over dry creeks, chopping away trees and digging down the banks of ditches in order to pass the train.  During the day we saw several herds of wild horses which fled at our approach.  We encamped at 3 o'clk P.M.  I cannot say exactly where.  

  On the 8" we still continued in a a [sic] N. easterly direction, traveling altogether by the compass and about 2 o'clk P.M. we struck the Canadian river and forded this treacherous stream at an unknown point encamping on the highland about a mile north of it.  Directly after we had encamped we were greeted by a heavy shower.

   On the 9" we moved through the dense woods along the Canadian touching

it several times, circling around a large bend, heretofore unknown to us, in consequence of the inaccuracy of the maps, and encamped in a beautiful prairie in the midst of a small Settlement of the Seminoles whose country we have again invaded.  About noon to-day we passed an elegant spring of ice cold water.  We were very loath to leave it.

 On the 10" we continued our course N. East to Mr. Aird's Store on the [?Little?] river about one mile from its mouth.  Mr. Aird and his brother are very clever gentlemen, natives of Pittsburgh Pa. and adopted citizens of the Seminole Nation.  He accompanied us to the Site of old Ft. Holmes on the opposite side of [?Little?] river near its junction with the Canadian.  This was an outpost established in 1826 and abandoned in 1836.  The buildings are all removed and the Site grown up with (weeds) bushes.  From here we proceeded to the North bank of the

[?Wenoka?] river, a narrow, high bank stream which in wet weather is impassible.

   July 11th.  We are now nearing Ft. Gibson and all are impatient to reach the end of our journey. To-day we crossed North Fork and Deep Fork, the latter a branch of the first which in its turn is a branch of the Canadian.  We found good fords on both.  We made 31 ½ miles and encamped five miles N. of Deep Fork.

We were greeted this afternoon by a heavy thunder storm.  One flash of lightning was very perceptibly felt by the entire party, knocking off the General's hat and almost felling Dr. Hubbard and myself from our horses.  We were all considerably frightened at first, and as soon as I could collect my senses, I looked around to see how many of the party were killed.  Fortunately all escaped with no more effect than a heavy shock.

    The weather has now become almost unbearable, the thermometer standing at 100' and upwards in the shade.

On the 12th our entire march was over a vast prairie with scarcely a tree to break the burning rays of the sun, and no water except what we found in stagnant pools.

 We reached the Creek Agency about 2 o'clk P.M. and encamped on a hill east of the village and near a well of clear cold water which was most welcome.

       On the following morning July 13" we concluded our march, reaching Fort Gibson at half past 8 o'clk A.M. just Six weeks [?to a day?] from the date of our departure.  During this time we have marched over Seven hundred & fifty miles, much of the way through the finest Section of Country the Sun ever Shone upon.

Headquarters District of the Indian Territory

   Fort Gibson - Cherokee Nation
          July 14, 1868

Bvt. Brig. Genl. C. McKeever
Asst. Adjt. Genl. Hed. Qrs. Dept. of the Missouri

    Fort Leavenworth Kansas

General:  I desire to inform the Commanding General of my return to this place on the thirteenth instant * & from the expedition on which I started the first of June and to submit for his information the following report.

    My route was as follows:  from this station via the Seminole Agency to Fort Arbuckle; thence West by North past the large prairie spring near an old Witchita Village to the Eastern extremity of the Witchita Mountains;  thence West along the South side of the mountains to old Camp Radziminski and the North Fork of Red River;  thence North East through the western portion of the mountains to old Fort Cobb, down the Valley of the Washita River to Fort Arbuckle and from that post to this in a course as nearly North East as possible without reference to roads.
    The route to Fort Arbuckle by way of the Seminole Agency, known as Capt. Robinsons road which has been used for military purposes for the last ten months is one hundred and seventy-eight (178) miles in length.  The road from this point to the Seminole Agency is very good with the exception of two or three bottoms and crossings of streams which are bad in wet weather; the road however is by no means direct the objective point being evidently the Agency which is fully twenty miles West of a direct line to Fort Arbuckle.   From the Agency to Arbuckle the road is not only indirect, bearing much too far to the West, but it is [crossed-out word] hilly, rough and has crossing it three or four considerable streams which are frequently quite impassable.

* (Insert)

Together with Capn. V. B. Hubbard,  Asst. Surg., Captain Alvord, Lieut. Woodward and the detachment of enlisted men at Regt. Hd. Qrs. 10th Cavalry.

At Fort Arbuckle I was careful in my examination of the station and it’s surroundings and am very decided in the opinion that it will be impolitic to go to any expense whatever in the construction of quarters, etc. with a view to making permanent accommodations for a force of more than four companies.  The saw mill from which all lumber for building purposes is necessarily furnished is now about thirty miles from the Post - as suitable logs can be found no nearer and this scarcity of timber with the transportation of other materials makes building very expensive.  I do not consider the position of the Post a good one for defense against either a civilized or savage enemy; it is low, almost surrounded by hills or higher ground with many ravines small streams bordered by dense thickets and similar coverings in its immediate vicinity.  To me the water (an unusually large spring with Wild Horse and other creeks) seems to have been the principal if not only natural advantage considered in selecting the site.  The Post is located near the center of the Chickasaw Nation the citizens of which are represented as quiet and peaceable getting along well among themselves and with no trouble requiring military surveillance or aid provided their western border can be protected from the marauding parties of the less civilized and troublesome tribes.  Fort Arbuckle is too Far East for any portion of this garrison to be much service in preventing or correcting the evils arising from troubles with or among the Indians inhabiting the country west of the Chickasaw and Seminoles.

Not even a mounted force could be moved from Arbuckle to the neighborhood of the wild tribes quickly enough to be of the practical advantage. I am decidedly of the opinion that for the purpose of controlling the tribes inclined to be lawless and troublesome, of preventing the marauding parties now so often visiting North Western Texas and of protecting the Chickasaw and Seminole borders and the peaceable tribes still farther West - who are endeavoring to fulfill their obligations to the government from molestation by the wild bands, a new post, to be garrisoned by cavalry mainly if not entirely - should be at once established West of Fort Arbuckle and that the establishment of such a post will render four companies an ample garrison for Fort Arbuckle.  The old log buildings at that post can be repainted so as to comfortably accommodate four companies with their officers the storehouse too should be completed and if practicable shelter provided for the horses of one or two companies of cavalry. But I do not deem it advisable from any point of view to erect any new buildings at Fort Arbuckle or permanently increase the garrison of the post beyond four companies.  I have already expressed my belief in the expediency of establishing a new military post in this territory West of Fort Arbuckle.  I gave particular attention to the selection of the best location for such a station.  On the map of this District furnished by the Engineer Bureau, a “Proposed New Post - 1807.”  is laid down at the

Spring at the head of Rush Creek near the Western boundary of the Chickasaw Nation and the old Witchita Village.  This point is eighteen miles North and forty-six (46) miles West from Fort Arbuckle - the shortest practicable route between being about fifty (50) miles.  I think this hardly far enough from Arbuckle.  The Spring is a very fine one, located in the midst of an extensive open prairie.  There is neither timber nor stone fit for building within several miles and very little wood even fit for fuel near the spring.  A thorough examination of the country in the vicinity of this Prairie Spring convinced me that it was not a desirable location for a Post.  Farther West, however, at a point eight (8) miles North and seventy (70) miles West from Fort Arbuckle the most practicable route being about seventy five (75) miles I found what I consider on the whole the best location for a military post in the South-Western portion of this territory.  It is a tract of high level prairie land containing about two hundred acres -  situated just at the base of the range of hills which are the Eastern extremity of the Witchita Mountains.  Mount Scott the highest peak of the Witchita is about eight miles West-North-West; a perpendicular cliff of Traprock Known by the Indians as The Medicine Bluff is a mile and a half West by No.; immediately West of the plateau and fifteen feet lower than it crossed out words: and between it and the bluff are three or four hundred

acres of level prairie land.  The northern boundary of the plateau is a beautiful, pure stream of good size running in a deep pebbly bed from Springs in the mountains North and West of Mount Scott just at the foot of the cliff mentioned and called Medicine Bluff Creek.  In passing the plateau this stream joins the main Caché Creek and that there flows at the North-East and East sides there being between the high ground and the creek at the East a meadow of two or three hundred acres fully thirty feet lower but dry, never overflowed and of remarkable fertility.  So the South traversed only by ravines dry water courses and Caché Creek with its branches - the high prairie extends to the Red River.  The water of the creek than which none could be more  pure and healthy is abundant for the men and animals of a large command.  There are besides, within a short distance, a number of fine never failing Springs, some having strong mineral properties from coal, iron, salt, & timber suitable for building purposes is not at all abundant anywhere in the south-western portion of the territory but there is more oak of different kinds, cottonwood, walnut, pecan, ash, elm, hackberry, mulberry and china upon the Caché Creek and its branches than anywhere else.  Excellent stone for building, of several varieties, and in unlimited quantity, can be easily quarried within a short distance.  Good limestone is also abundant.  The grazing in this section surpasses anything I ever saw.  The varieties of

grass are numerous and among them are the buffalo mosquite and gamma grasses abundant and especially nutritious.  Buffalo, cattle and horses graze here the year ‘round, keeping in excellent condition.  While old Fort Cobb was garrisoned, hay was made here and hauled almost forty miles to that post. The climate is delightful and cannot be otherwise than healthy, - a strong southerly breeze prevails.  I examined the country well in all directions and found no standing water or moist bottoms - all is high and dry.  This is the locality of which General Marcy in his work “Army Life on the Border” (page 127) says, “It commands an extended view of the country to the North, South and East.  From it’s commanding position it is well secured against surprise and is by nature one of the most defensible places I have seen.”  I believe that a force of four or six companies of cavalry at this point would be more effective than if stationed in any other locality I have visited and would give security at the same time to Northern Texas, the Chickasaws, the Caddos, Witchita and other friendly Indians who in this territory are endeavoring to remain quiet and peaceable - as all points where trouble is likely to occur can readily be reached by mounted troops placed here.  Old Camp Radziminski, occupied during the winter of 1858-9, I found to be on the West

side of Otter Creek and considerably farther North  than represented by any map.  It is closely surrounded by high rocky hills, did very well for a winter camp but is in a very poor country, destitute of wood, almost of grass and with a great scarcity of good water.  I do not think the locality at all suitable for a post although at certain seasons of the year one or two companies of a garrison at the East end of the mountains might be temporarily stationed advantageously near the western extremity on Otter Creek -  and supplied without difficulty along the south side of the mountains.  The whole valley of the Washita River for a distance of twenty miles is now commonly called Fort Cobb.  The ruins of the old post itself are however several miles farther up the river than any of the Indian villages, agencies or trading posts and I could not find anyone except Indians who had ever been there. It was represented to me as an almost barren prairie, a region destitute of wood, water, grass, etc, and I was consequently surprised when on visiting the place July 1st.  I found it to be located on Pond Creek, a beautiful stream on the North of the Washita in a fertile and well wooded country.  The water and timber are better in the immediate vicinity of the post than at any other point I saw on the Washita River - and I like the situation of the post very well.  The grass is not good near by and as before stated while Cobb was

garrisoned hay was cut and hauled about forty miles from the vicinity of Medicine Bluff on Caché Creek.  I do not think it would be advisable to re-establish Fort Cobb, as under the present circumstances the location described on Cashé Creek - would be better.  Believing that before very long all the troops in this District can be used to better advantage at stations beyond the present Western boundaries of the Cherokee, Creek, Seminole and Chickasaw Nations - I desired to ascertain the practicability of opening a supply route from Fort Riley or Fort unclear nearly direct to the eastern point of the Witchita Mts.  (*)

 (insert)  The information in regard to this subject which I derived while in the vicinity of Fort Cobb from frontiersmen, traders, and indians leaves little doubt in my mind that an excellent road can be made with very little labor from Mount Scott to Fort Harker? or Fort Riley - bearing East to cross the Washita below Fort Cobb, avoid the Salt Plains and cross the Arkansas near the mouth of the Little Arkansas.  + (Insert Paragraph below-)  + I shall endeavor by hereafter personally visiting that section to enable myself to give still more definite information regarding this matter.  It might be necessary on account of the length of the route and to look out for the Indians in the neighborhood of the Salt Plainsto have a post in the territory near the southern line of Kansas.

Until the opening of that route a post at the East end of the Witchita Mountains could be supplied from this dépôt, by a road via the Seminole Agency not exceeding two hundred (200) miles in length or by the way of Fort Arbuckle a route not over twenty (20) miles longer.  The valley of the Washita River from a point five miles below Fort Cobb to some distance this side of the Chickasaw line is wide and apparently fertile but has no good water in it.  It is in that section that Colonel Leavenworth established his Agency for the Comanche and Kiowa tribes and Major Shanklin has also gathered his Indians there, the Witchitas, Waco’s, Tomoccaroes, Ke. Hies, Caddos and Anadagheos.  Col.Leavenworth’s Agancy very injudiciously located in the brush on a hill side five miles south of the Washita with not water enough near him for drinking purposes of the people alone - and where - if the Indians settle ‘round him as intended they must drive their stock five miles to water.  (Inserted paragraph written sideways)    This Agency too instead of being West or Southwest of the section occupies by the Reserve Indians - Witchitas and affiliated bands - (namely within the boundaries of the Kiowa and Comanche Reserves as defined in the treaty of 1867) is in their midst - Major Shankln’s agency being still father up the Washita.
I believe that this location of their agency was the first cause of the discontent among Comanches and Kiowas - their want of confidence in their Agent Leavenworth and his uncertain,

vacillating conduct towards them - together with the failure on the part of the contractors to furnish and of the Agents to deliver the annuities and the promised supplies increased the disaffection - and finally many of them returned to the plains.  The Kiowas have not fulfilled their obligations under the treaty of last autumn - and early this summer left the Washita Valley and returned to their wild life near the Salt Plains - more than a hundred miles North of Fort Cobb.  The Comanche tribe, although really one people, is divided into several bands quite different in their habits and character.  The largest band, called Ouah-a-dc-de-chatz-Ken-na. (Antelope Eaters or users)have never come in to treat for peace but remain hostile inhabiting the Staked Plain regions and preying upon Northern Mexico and Texas.  The Yani-pa-ri-Kos (Root diggers) were included in the last treaty but never kept really quiet; from their band marauding parties were often sent to Texas and children as well as horses brought back.  They were encamped around Col. Leavenworth for a while and soon discovered that while they remained quiet they got very little but by intimidating the vulnerable Agent they could obtain abundant supplies.  Upon this principle they acted until the subsistence stores gave out - then after an unusual demonstration

in which no one was hurt, however, they also moved North and are with or near the Kiowas.  Of the bands of the Comanches who profess to be peaceable this is undoubtedly the most troublesome.  The Cos-tche-tegh- Kas (Buffalo Eaters) a small band, live and act with the Yamparikas.  The Senerva, Se-chatz-Kenna and Moocha bands are small and unimportant; they were in the Washita Valley for a time but have gone North of the Canadian.  The No-Ko-nees (Wanderers) and Pene-tegh-Kas (Honey Eaters) remain on the Washita in Eureka Valley (the name Col. Leavenworth has given to his neighborhood) and the Cottonwood Grove - five miles below.  They give little trouble and seem well disposed - although hunger makes the former band grumble considerably.  The Pene-tech-Ka is the Texas band of the Comanche tribe and for years has remained near settlements giving no trouble of consequence.  They are now tending small patches of corn at Cottonwood Grove.  To-sa-wi (Silver-brooch) a man of much influence in the councils of the Comanches is their chief and his endeavor is to keep his people from the plains and bring them to a state of semi-civilization that they may be classed with the Witchitas and Caddos.  It appears that the Kiowas with the Yampariko and other troublesome bands of the Comanches have extended their depredations to the domain of the Navajos in New Mexico and that tribe has in retaliation

Sent marauding parties East.  Meanwhile the bands who committed the depredations in New Mexico have moved North and left the Witchitas and other peaceable Indians remaining in the Valley of the Washita to stand the brunt of the Navajo attacks.  In consequence of this the peaceable tribes have lost stock in considerable numbers and been compelled to fall back farther East for safety to their animals and lodges - abandoning their many little patches of cover.  These bands claim and I believe justly that while they remain quiet and peaceable upon the lands allotted to them and fulfill in everyway the requirements of their treaties the government is bound to protect them from the depredations of the wild tribes.  The same Indians complain that the Agents neglect them and give the main portion of the presents and supplies to the less worthy faithless band and I am satisfied that such is the fact.  (Here insert paragraph in margin)  Before reaching Fort Arbuckle I had met the Agents Col. Leavenworth and Major Shanklin and Special Subsistence Agent Caldwell En route to Fort Cobb and while in that neighborhood I met all the traders; interpreters and other whites living there and the Chiefs of all the tribes remaining in that section.  I conversed at length with all and altho’ it was impossible to gather positive proof of special improper acts on the part of the Indian Agents - the information I received from all parties left no doubt in my mind that Col. Leavenworth encouraged the wilder Indians in their marauding by secretly giving large presents to obtain the captive children whom he nominally demanded  - and by increasing the supplies whenever they threatened him or his goods.  He also, as has already been reported by Captain Walsh sent to Fort Arbuckle in great haste for troops to protect him and when asked by the Indians why the troops were there - he disclaimed all knowledge of the cause.

I believe that the Witchitas, Wacos, Caddos, Penetighka Comanches, etc. who really deserve credit and encouragement for remaining faithful and endeavoring to become gradually self sustaining by raising corn and stock have been constantly neglected.  their goods and supplies given to the wild tribes. 
All the chiefs met me in an apparently friendly spirit - expressed a universal desire for peace and seemed to think that others would be no trouble if their people regularly received the annuities and supplies which the Government by its treaties with them is pledged to deliver.
The command which accompanied me consisted of parts of the four companies of cavalry under Capt. Walsh and a detachment of infantry under Lt. Jacobs. This proved efficient - the officers and men discharging their duties with promptness and energy - and on the fourth of July the whole force - after a march of about four hundred miles, returned to Ft. Arbuckle in fine condition.
I left that station again on the 6th and in coming here took a new route. Travelling by compass in a North-Easterly course between the Seminole Agency road and the Old road via North Fork Town. I made the march in seven days with a Train - the measured distance being one hundred fifty-seven (157) miles, seventy-five (75) between Fort Arbuckle and the junction of Little River with the Canadian eightly-two (82) from that point to this. It was impossible of course to find the very shortest and best on one trip made in haste - but I obtained a good knowledge of the country between the two posts. An excellent road, mostly prairie not exceeding eighty (80) miles in length can with little labor be laid out in a nearly direct line from this post to the Canadian at the mouth of Little River. The Deep Fork and North Fork of the Canadian and the We-wo-Ka, a branch of North Fork are the only streams of any size to be crossed. They are almost always fordable and the WewoKa which has the most crossing and bottom can be avoided entirely by bearing a little East and crossing North Fork below its mouth.

In coming from Arbuckle I crossed the Canadian a few miles higher up than I had intended, above the mouth of Little River.  but a good ridge road can be made from the ford on the Canadian just below Little River, which will be a practicable and nearly direct route to Arbuckle from sixty (60) to sixty-five (65) miles in length.  
By a road between this station and Fort Arbuckle via mouth of Little River, the distance will not exceed one hundred and forty five (145) miles, while the road will avoid the bad streams on both the other routes and be in every way better than either of them.
The shortening of the route will much lessen the expense of transportation to Fort Arbuckle and I shall therefore give further attention to the matter of the new road as soon as practicable.
I have seen no map of the Territory which is not incorrect in important particulars and generally unreliable.  I shall cause to be prepared and will forward as soon as possible a Journal of the march giving in detail all the information relative to the country traversed, the roads &etc which can be of interest or value at Department Headquarters - accompanied by an accurate map of that portion of the District through which I passed.
Very respectfully
Your obedient servant
B. H. Grierson
Colonel Tenth Regt Cavalry
Brevet Major General USA
Commanding District of the Indian Territory
